ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: the full process of pitching, planning, outlining, and writing a TV script; how a writers room works
You learn how to write scripts, and you really get to learn about how the industry works.
All the steps to writing a television pilot, how to parse a tv script, and just general knowledge about the industry at large

The course is focused around the TV drama pilot, and we got to learn about all kinds of screenwriting techniques (dialogue, monologues, structure, character building, foils, subtext, etc.), plus Professor Tracy answers any questions you have about the entertainment industry and how shows get made. Very interesting and engaging stuff!
I learned so much about how to structure narrative, build characters, develop voice, etc in scripts and how to analyze other writers material.
I learned a lot about the TV writing process and about the industry.
I learned a lot about how television is made and how to make it.
Reading and analyzing TV scripts, how the industry works, some writing exercises

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: All strengths. Only wish we had kept a running list of show recommendations!

It's a very engaging class, and the professor is great at conveying information. There might be many script classes, but this class is very specific to TV that you learn lot each class. The professor treats each class as an opportunity for us to casually talk about TV, and these conversations are surprisingly informative.
The only weakness is that the feedback for assignments isn't very clear. Even if all the comments are positive, you still end up with a mediocre grade every time...

This assignments are great and well-structured. The scripts we read are all varied and interesting and lend themselves to great discussion. 
I wished we spent a little more time in class sharing ideas and workshopping with one another as a whole rather than in breakout groups. I think it would be helpful as a group to discuss script problems we're having, and I also felt a bit isolated from those I didn't small group with as I didn't get to hear much about what they were working on.
Super fun course with excellent material (you will read fantastic pilots from some all time TV shows). No further improvements!

The format of the course kept me very engaged throughout. It felt very informal, like I was a part of a book club that met every week and I was able to learn and discuss with my peers while still remaining on task. I think some sort of incentive to work outside of the classroom wouldve been good to maintain interaction with the material.

It was interesting to read a wide variety of scripts and to take our own projects through the various stages of script development. I think starting our projects earlier in the semester would be good so that we could have time to write a full pilot by the end of the semester.
Its a good class but the assignments should be spaced more evenly through the semester.
The readings, assignments, and projects were all great and immensely helpful. Could maybe have a bit more focus on writing?

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Was fantastic. Favorite class easily.
Yes!! Can't recommend it enough. This is the most practical film/tv class at Yale.
If you're at all interested in TV writing, take this course. Not only is it a great time, but it sets you up well for a strong writing sample and the skills to continue writing pilots in the future.
Yes, absolutely! Favorite course of the semester. The class is chill, the discussion is great, the pilots you read are super entertaining and great examples of peak television.

I would highly recommend this course. I think the curriculum was great, I think the professor was great, and its just a very fun class to participate in every week. Going to class was actually a stress reliever.
Yes, its very fun and informative.
Yes, this is a really great class especially if you have any interest in writing for television.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the world of TV writing.
